journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: An innovative tri-axes micro-power receiver for inductively wireless power transmission

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan City 70101, Republic of China.email: nortren@mail.ncku.edu.tw

abstract.p: An innovative tri-axes micro-power receiver is proposed and studied for wireless magnetic energy transmission. The tri-axes micro-power receiver mainly consists of two sets of three-dimensional micro-solenoids and one set of planar micro-coils in which individual iron core is all embedded. The three sets of micro-coils/micro-solenoids are designed to be orthogonal to each other. Therefore, no matter which direction the input magnetic flux is present along, the supplied magnetic energy can be harvested and transformed into electric power by the proposed micro-power receiver in wireless sense. Not only the dead zone of receiving power is greatly reduced, but also transformation efficacy of magnetic energy into electric power can be much enhanced. By Governing Equations Analysis (GEA), based on Biot-Savart law and Faraday's law, the mathematical description upon power transmission from transmitter to receiver is established. The estimation error on power transmission by commercial software, Ansoft Maxwell, based on finite element method, is revealed, in comparison to GEA method. Moreover, the design parameters of tri-axes micro-receiver are examined and verified for follow-up fabrication and experiments. Particularly for the micro electro mechanical systems process, the isotropic etching technique is employed to micro-machine the inverse-trapezoid fillister for solenoid at receiver, so that the copper wire can be successfully electroplated. Therefore, the adhesion between micro-coils and fillister is hence much enhanced as well.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Due to the drastic progress of micro-machining technique, the micro-devices and micro-systems, such as wireless sensor networks, capsule endoscopes, micro-drug delivery systems, radio-frequency identification, micro-robots, and tire pressure monitoring units, are gradually mature and commercialized [1–4]. In order to work for a long period of time, most devices require continuously supplied power. No matter the power is transmitted by electrical wire or supplied by embedded battery, the size of the device is imposed be greatly increased. Moreover, owing to the requirement to work under certain particular environments, many kinds of wireless devices, such as micro-endoscopes and micro-drug delivery systems, cannot carry large-size batteries. Besides, the power supply for these devices cannot be terminated over certain time intervals. Therefore, the shortcomings of current power supply modules in micro-systems have to be overcome so that the applications of micro-devices can be diversified.

Inductively Wireless Power Transmission (IWPT) and Micro Electro Mechanical Systems (MEMS) energy harvester are the two potential technologies to break the aforesaid bottleneck of power supply for tiny or micro-devices. The principle of MEMS energy harvester, such as vibration-based MEMS energy harvester, MEMS thermoelectric generator, and MEMS acoustic energy harvester, is to harvest energy from ambient environment and then transform it into electrical power [5–8]. However, it is applicable only if the ambient environment has sufficient energy intensity. Instead, wireless power transmission can be actively applied by the cooperation of receiver embedded in the micro-locomotive device. In addition, the received power by the IWPT is considerably stable. This inspires our study on IWPT and micro-scale energy receivers. The IWPT proposed in this article mainly consists of a centimetre-scale magnetic flux transmitter and a micrometre-scale receiver [9, 10]. As the magnetic flux transmitter is energized by the applied alternating voltage, the magnetic field is generated simultaneously. The electrical power can be, in wireless sense, delivered by transmitter to receiver if the distribution and intensity of magnetic flux are appropriately designed.

The magnetic flux receiver is one of the key devices for IWPT. For IWPT, the central axes of transmitter and receiver are usually assumed to be perfectly aligned in most reported literatures. For example, the receiver by Samad [11] and its applications, such as miniaturized ignition units by Rodríguez [12], MEMS thermal sensor by Suster [13] and the implantable devices by Sauer [14], are all based on this assumption. However, in practice, the misalignment of receiver with respect to the central axis of transmitter is always present due to inaccuracy of assembly or imperfect fabrication. To evaluate the transformation efficacy from transmitter to receiver, the mathematical analysis and simulation for misalignment between transmitter and receiver was reported by a few researchers [15, 16]. For example, in order to solve the misalignment problem, an adjustable platform for wireless power transmission was designed by Gao [17]. The transmitter is designed as a set of multi-group windings and placed beneath the platform. Depending on the precision of assembly, the central axes of transmitter and embedded receiver in micro-robot can be aligned to some extent. Another example is the approach by Wang [18]. To overcome misalignment problem, the location of the receiver is designed to be adjustable.

As a matter of fact, our work is initiated by the application of capsule endoscopes under the financial support of National Science Council (NSC), Republic of China. Capsule endoscope has gradually become an acceptable approach to detect the early-stage malignant tumour in human digestive system, especially for the colon sections. However, most of the photographs taken by the capsule endoscope are of no use, owing to the illumination supplied tothe embedded charge coupled device is fairly insufficient. In order to fully support the electricity consumption of the battery within the capsule endoscope, IWPT is applied in our work. In other words, an outside-body power supply system is required if the electricity consumption ends up as a serious concern for bio-MEMS applications. This research is focused on the micrometre-scale magnetic power receiver design for an outside-body power supply system, as shown in Fig. 1, in which a power transmitter is equipped and its posture and intensity of transmitted power are both real-time adjusted by a PC-based controller, according to the location and posture of the capsule endoscope as it proceeds through the entire digestive system. Fig. 1
An example for the application of proposed micro-power receiver under wireless power transmission

In this article, an innovative tri-axes micro-power receiver, mainly consisting of two sets of micro-solenoids and one set of micro-planar coils, is proposed and investigated. The two sets of micro-solenoids and one set of micro-planar coils are deliberately designed so that they are orthogonal to each other. Once the central axis of micro-receiver is misaligned with respect to the central axis of transmitter, the potentially missed components of magnetic flux by a set of micro-coil can be harvested by the other two sets of micro-coils. Besides, for each set of micro-planar coils/micro-solenoids, an individual iron core is embedded so that the efficacy to preserve the transmitted energy can be much improved. To more precisely estimate the received power and efficiency of energy transmission, Governing Equations Analysis (GEA) on power transmission from transmitter to receiver is constructed. Furthermore, it can be used to verify the design of the tri-axes micro-power receiver such that the geometric dimensions of the micro-receiver are obtained for follow-up fabrication and experiments. Finally, the fabrication processes by micro-machining technology is proposed to realize the design of tri-axes micro-power receiver.

sec.title: 2 DESIGN OF TRI-AXES MICRO-POWER RECEIVER
sec.p:
The schematic diagram of tri-axes micro-power receiver is shown in Figs 2 and 3. The tri-axes micro-power receiver is composed of two sets micro-solenoids, i.e. Sets A and B and one set of micro-planar coils, i.e. Set C. Micro-solenoid Set A (or Set B) consists of two individual micro-solenoid modules parallel to each other. Each pair of micro-solenoids is wound by the same copper wire. The iron core is embedded in each micro-solenoid. The magnetic fluxes in X- and Y-directions are to be harvested by the two pairs of micro-solenoid modules, Sets A and B, respectively. These two sets of micro-solenoids, Sets A and B, are perpendicular to each other like a square. On the other hand, the magnetic flux in Z-direction is to be harvested by the set of micro-planner coils C placed at the centre of the receiver. Set C consists of four identical individual micro-coils (C1, C2, C3, and C4) in which the iron cores are embedded and encircled around the central axis of Z-axis. In other words, by Sets A, B, and C, all components of magnetic flux around the vicinity of receiver can be harvested, as shown in Figs 4 and 5. Fig. 2
Schematic diagram of tri-axes micro-power receiver Fig. 3
Micro-solenoid and micro-planar coil sets Fig. 4
Relation between magnetic flux and tri-axes micro-power receiver Fig. 5
Individual component of magnetic flux harvested by tri-axes micro-power receiver

Based on the structure design, no matter in whichdirection the micro-device moves/rotates, the components of magnetic flux by any transmitter can be harvested by the tri-axes micro-power receiver which is attached with the locomotive micro-device, shown in Fig. 5. The potential dead zone of micro-receiver and the misalignment impact can be much reduced. In addition, the induced voltage at receiver is directly proportional to the change rate of magnetic flux through the cross-sectional area of micro-coil. In addition, the iron core, whose material is of low magnetic resistance, is embedded in each micro-coil. The iron core is employed to attract and collect the magnetic flux like a water pipe with respect to the water flow. Therefore, the electromagnetic transformation efficacy from magnetic energy into electric energy can be much enhanced.

sec.title: 3 GEA ON IWPT
sec.p: In order to evaluate the performance of the proposed micro-receiver, the GEA, according to Biot-Savart law and Faraday's law, from transmitter to micro-receiver, is established. First, the vector potential and magnetic flux density constructed by the energized transmitter are derived by Biot-Savart law. The vector potential and magnetic flux density are used to further evaluate the induced voltage at micro-receiver by Faraday's law. Nevertheless, the GEA from transmitter to the tri-axes micro-power receiver is considerably complicated and non-linear. Therefore, in order to examine the superiority of GEA, the commercial software Ansoft Maxwell with its subroutine Transient Solver, based on finite element method (FEM), is employed as a benchmark. To sum up, not only the induced voltage at tri-axes micro-power receiver can be predicted, but also the design parameters, such as sizes of coil and iron core, can be examined for later-on fabrication and experiments.

sec.title: 3.1 Vector potential and magnetic flux density
sec.p:
The structure and dimensional definitions of transmitter and micro-receiver are shown in Fig. 6. The micro-receiver shown in Fig. 6 is the side view of the solenoid Set A (or Set B) at the proposed tri-axes micro-power receiver. According to Biot-Savart law, the vector potential, A→, constructed by an energized electrical wire at Point P(R,θ,φ), can be expressed as follows [19] (1) where μ0=4π×10-7(H/m) is the permeability in vacuum, l the electrical current applied at the electrical wire, C′ the boundary of electrical wire, R′ the distance between the centre of coil segment, dl→', and point P(R,θ,φ). In our work, the transmitter is wound around the embedded iron core like a set of spiral-type planner coils with n turns. Each turn of spiral-type planner coils from the utmost inner diameter to the utmost outer diameter of transmitter is numbered as 1, 2, …,nth,…, and nt orderly, where nt represents the number of total turns. The vector potential at P(R,θ,φ) contributed by the utmost inner turn of the spiral-type planner coils, i.e. numbered as 1, can be represented as follows (2) Fig. 6
Dimensional definitions of transmitter and micro-receiver

The subscript of vector potential A→i, i, is corresponding to the ith turn of coil, R the distance between the centre of area surrounded by the coil and point P(R,θ,φ), a the radius of area enclosed by the coil winding, and θ and φ the angular displacements with respect to +X-axis and +Y-axis, respectively. The relation, a→y=-a→φ, based on geometry in Fig. 7, evidently holds true. The overall vector potential by the transmitter, shown in Fig. 6, can be described as follows (3) where d represents the diameter of wire. By the principle of conservation of magnetic flux, ∇·B→=0, and its alternative representation, ∇·(∇×A→)=0 [19, 20], the magnetic flux density B→ can be expressed as B→=∇×A→. Therefore, the magnetic flux density at point P(R,θ,φ) can be further represented as (4) Where ∇=∂∂R+1R∂∂θ+1Rsinθ∂∂φ represents the gradient operator in spherical coordinate (a→R,a→θ,a→φ). Fig. 7
Segment dl→' by Cartesian coordinate

sec.title: 3.2 Induced voltage at micro-receiver
sec.p: The induced voltage at the jth turn of micro-receiver, shown in Fig. 6, can be derived by Faraday's law as [19] (5) where E→j represents the corresponding electric field intensity at the jth turn of micro-receiver, B→j the corresponding magnetic flux density through the cross-sectional area of the jth turn of micro-receiver. The induced voltage at receiver by GEA, i.e. Vj=∮cE→j·dl→, can be derived by Stokes's theorem as follows (6) where s denotes the area encircled by the jth turn of micro-receiver and c the boundary of s. The magnetic flux φj through the cross-sectional area of the jth turn of micro-receiver can be expressed as follows (7)

By equations (6) and (7), the total induced voltage, Vt, at micro-receiver can be summed by (8) where n′ represents the coil turns of micro-receiver. Equation (8) can be applied to describe the mathematical relation from transmitter to micro-receiver under IWPT.

sec.title: 3.3 Performance evaluation on tri-axesmicro-power receiver
sec.p:
In order to evaluate the efficacy of the proposed micro-receiver, the mathematical relation from transmitter to micro-receiver by GEA has been derived and concluded by equation (8). On the other hand, the commercial software Ansoft Maxwell with its transient solver is employed to compare with the simulation result for the proposed GEA approach. The parameters of the transmitter and the micro-receiver are listed in Table 1. The dimensional descriptions for micro-receiver are shown in Fig. 8. In fact, Fig. 8 shows the top view of the micro-receiver presented in Fig. 6. The induced voltage at micro-receiver by GEA and FEM approaches is shown in Fig. 9(a). The computation error by FEM, shown in Fig. 9(b), with respect to GEA method is evident. Although Ansoft Maxwell can be employed to solve the equations of time-variant magnetic field, a certain degree of simulation error is generated such as: (1) computation error due to the boundary setup which is necessary and prerequisite for Ansoft simulation. If the enclosed domain of the transmitter/receiver is large enough to cover the entire studied device (particularly for the centimetre-scale transmitter), the computation load is too heavy to be completed. On the contrary, if the enclosed domain is scaled-down so that the dimension of transmitter is shrunk from 50 cm to 50 µm, the computation error, shown in Fig. 9(b), is fairly severe. (2) Serious mismatch due to un-neglectable difference upon scales for transmitter and receiver enclosed simultaneously for Ansoft simulation. The scale of receiver is about a few tens to hundreds of micrometre at most but the scale of the transmitter is more than 50 cm. That is, these equations (i.e. GEA) are still necessary to obtain more precise solutions. Fig. 8
Dimensions of micro-receiver Fig. 9
(a) Induced voltage by FEM and GEA and (b) computation error by FEM with respect to GEA Table 1
Parameters for transmitter and micro-receiver on wireless power transmission

Number of windings (nt) 10 turns
Applied voltage (V) 400cos(2000πt)V
Dimension of micro-receiver Size
Cross-sectional size of micro-coil 20 × 20 µm2
Distance between transmitter and micro-receiver (z1) (Fig. 6) 50 mm
Half width of lower-layer coil of micro-solenoid, w (Fig. 8) 1.25 mm
Half height, h, is assumed as the half distance between the utmost lower-layercoil of micro-solenoid and the utmost upper-layer coil of micro-solenoid (Fig. 8) 0.5 mm

Number of windings of coils on micro-solenoids (Set A or Set B) 98 turns
Number of windings of coils at Set C 160 turns
Pitch of windings 40 µm
Length, width, and height of iron core embedded in Set A/B (Fig. 3(a)) 2000 × 428 × 85 µm3
Length, width, and height of iron core embedded in Set C (Fig. 3(b)) 500 × 500 × 180 µm3

First, the transmitter is energized by an alternating voltage. The induced voltage at each micro-coil set is shown in Fig. 10. The distribution of induced magnetic flux density at receiver is shown in Fig. 11. It is noticed that at time instant 0.65 ms, the induced voltage reaches the maximum (Fig. 10). The corresponding maximum of magnetic flux density, shown in Fig. 11(d), is about 1.8 T. The applied voltage at transmitter is a little less than 400 V. Theoretically, the achievable magnetic density at the iron core is a little more than 2 T so that the result of induced flux density by the proposed design has not been saturated yet even if the applied voltage is set as high as 400 V. Fig. 10
Induced voltage at tri-axes micro-power receiver Fig. 11
Magnetic flux distribution at iron core from 0.55 to 0.7 ms

The efficiency of power transmission is evaluated by following equation (9) where Po(W) and Pi(W) denote the received power by receiver and input power applied at transmitter. Po and Pi can be calculated by P=(1/T)∫0 TV(t)I(t)dt, where T, V(t), and I(t) represent the period, voltage, and current, respectively. The received power and efficiency at three coil sets, Set A, Set B, and Set C, are summarized and listed in Table 2. Table 2
Efficiency of tri-axes micro-power receiver by Ansoft

Notes: z1, distance between transmitter and micro-receiver; β, misalignment angle between transmitter and receiver.

The experimental test rig constructed for wireless power transmission is shown in Fig. 12. The orientation of receiver is altered by Rotary Stepping Motor #1. The distance between transmitter and receiver is controlled by the Linear Motor which moves linearly along Z-direction. The linear variable differential transformer is equipped to detect the real-time distance and fed to the PC-based controller. On the other hand, the orientation of transmitter is adjusted by Rotary Stepping Motor #2. The PC-based controller is employed to tune the amplitude of applied current at transmitter and the misalignment between transmitter and receiver, according to the location and orientation of locomotive micro-receiver. In order words, no matter where the micro-receiver goes by, the received electrical power at receiver can be retained constant. Fig. 12
Experimental platform for wireless power transmission

The misalignment angle, between the central axis of transmitter and that of Set A at receiver, can be adjusted by tuning the position of the rotary stepping motors and linear motor simultaneously. The induced voltage at Set A under various misalignment angles between transmitter and receiver is shown in Fig. 13. In comparison, the peak of induced voltage along transversal axis is 12 per cent and 35 per cent of the maximum along the perpendicular axis by GEA and FEM approaches, respectively. The efficiency andpower received by Set A at receiver are listed in Table 3. It can be observed that the efficiency is degraded as the misalignment degree becomes larger. Fig. 13
Induced voltage at Set A of receiver under various misalignment degrees between transmitter and receiver Table 3
Efficiency of tri-axes micro-power receiver by experiment
Conditions z1 = 50 mm
Set A β = 0° β = 30° β = 60° β = 90°
Received power (mW) 0.787 0.656 0.376 0.109
Efficiency (× 10-4%) 1.9816 1.6524 0.9462 0.2745
Notes: z1 , distance between transmitter and micro-receiver; β, misalignment angle between transmitter and receiver.

sec.title: 4 FABRICATION OF TRI-AXES MICRO-POWER RECEIVER
sec.p:
The fabrication processes of tri-axes micro-power receiver can be divided into three stages. The fabrication process for the bottom layer of micro-solenoid and micro-planar coil is described in Section 4.1. At second stage, the iron cores of micro-solenoid and upper layer of micro-solenoid are fabricated. At final stage, the iron cores at the centre of micro-planar coils and three layers of micro-planar coil are constructed. In our work, the micro-coils are fabricated onto the inverse-trapezoid fillister so that the contact angle of plated wire against fillister can be increased. Besides, the conventional design defect, too much void within the plated copper wire, can be prevented [21–23]. However, the housing for micro-coils and iron cores has to be built against the inner wall of the inverse-trapezoid fillister. If the photo-resist (PR) is coated into fillister by spin coater, it is inevitable that the PR would be over-stacked at the corners of the fillister. Therefore, the thickness of PR on the inner wall of the fillister would not be uniform, as shown in Fig. 14(a). The over-piled-up PR at the corners of the fillister causes that the spots (i.e. Type A in Fig. 14(b)) to be electroplated for micro-coils against the inner walls of the fillister after photo-lithography is still covered by PR, as shown in Fig. 14(b). In order to make the seed layer at the locations, to be electroplated against inner walls of the fillister, entirely exposed, the over-stacked PR on the spot to be electroplated for micro-coil has to be completely removed. On the contrary, the spots (i.e. Type B in Fig. 14(b)) need to be completely covered by the PR after photo-lithography. One of the potential solutions is to prolong the exposure time. However, as the exposure time is extended to be over 250 s, though the overall PR, to be electroplated locations for micro-coil against inner wall of the fillister, is much reduced but still cannot be completely exposed. Due to over-exposure, the expected ‘rectangular’ strips of coil housing have been imposed to become ‘I’ in geometry, as shown in Fig. 14(b), all over the bottom of the fillister. It implies that the exposure time duration on AZ-4620 PR has to be limited below 250 s. In other words, extension of exposure time duration does not work fine in this case. Therefore, another type of PR, KMPR, is employed as the material of hosing for low-layer coil. By experimental trial, the required exposure time for KMPR, whose thickness is tuned between 30 and 65 µm, is almost the same: 55–60 s, as shown in Figs 15(a) and 16. Owing to its superior optical transmittance, the light beam by exposure is easier to penetrate KMPR, compared with AZ-4620 PR. Hence, the required exposure time on KMPR can be shortened. From the experiments, shown in Figs 15(a) and 16, once the KMPR is employed as the material of hosing for thelow-layer coil, not only the seed layer of micro-coils can be successfully constructed but also the width of each strip of the PR walls becomes constant. Fig. 14
(a) In Fillister, the PR coated by spin coater is inevitable to be over-stacked at the corners of Fillister (thickness of PR ≈ 7µm, exposure time > 250 s); (b) owing to over-exposure, the expected ‘rectangular’ strips of housing have been imposed to become ‘I’ in geometry (thickness of PR ≈ 7µm, exposure time > 250 s) Fig. 15
(a) KMPR employed as material of housing (b) and (c) side view of micro-solenoid housing (thickness of PR ≈ 30 µm, exposure time = 55–60 s) Fig. 16
KMPR employed as material of housing (thickness of PR ≈ 65µm, exposure time = 55 - 60 s)

The fabrication processes for the bottom coil of micro-solenoids A/B and first layer of micro-planar coils C are shown in Fig. 17. The detail of fabrication processes is introduced as follows.
A thin film of silicon nitride (Si3Nx), with thickness 100 nm, is deposited on the wafer by plasma-enhanced chemical vapour deposition. This layer of Si3Nx is used as the etching mask prepared for the KOH non-isotropic etching which will be undertaken later. A thin film of aluminium (Al), with thickness 100 nm, is deposited above the Si3Nx film on the wafer. Al is not etched by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) so that this layer can be used as an etching mask for ICP. The PR AZ-4620 is deposited onto the film of Al and then photo exposure process is undertaken so that the etching mask made by Al is patterned and defined. By using ICP, the etching mask made by Si3Nx is patterned and defined.
KOH solution with 45 per cent concentration is used for non-isotropic etching of silicon. The temperature and time are set as 80°C and 160 min, respectively, with stir. The inverse-trapezoid fillister, with depth 120 µm, is constructed.
The fabrication process of etching mask for iron core of micro-solenoid C is the same as (a).
KOH solution with 45 per cent concentration is used for non-isotropic etching of silicon. The temperature and time are set as 80°C and 20 min, respectively. The inverse-trapezoid fillister for iron core of micro-solenoid C, with depth 15 µm, is constructed.
A seed layer of chromium (Cr), with thickness 100 nm, is deposited by E-beam evaporator to enhance the coherence efficacy of copper layer, which is to be deposited in the follow-up electroplating process (g).
The PR KMPR is deposited on the wafer by automatic spin coating system and then photo exposure process is undertaken. The patterned KMPR is used as housing for bottom layer of micro-solenoids A/B and first layer of micro-planar coils C.
The copper layer is deposited into the housing by electroplating.
KMPR stripper and Cr etchant are used to remove KMPR and seed layer (Cr), respectively.
Fig. 17
Fabrication process for bottom-layer coil of micro-solenoid (A/B) and bottom-layer coil of micro-planar coils (C)

Finally, a few scanning electron micrographs (SEMs) of fabricated tri-axes micro-power receiver are shown in Fig. 18. Fig. 18
A few SEMs of fabricated tri-axes micro-power receiver

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSION
sec.p: In this research, an innovative tri-axes micro-power receiver is designed and proposed. The effect of design parameters (size of micro-power receiver and transmitter, current frequency applied at transmitter, etc.) upon the efficacy of the proposed micro-power receiver is investigated by the mathematic model on power transmission from transmitter to receiver. By tuning the design parameters, a certain degree of performance of tri-axes micro-power receiver can be ensured. The peak voltages of induced voltage by the micro-coils sets along X-axis, Y-axis, and Z-axis are 100, 100, and 63 mV, respectively, as the frequency of power transmission is retained at 1 kHz and the volume of the entire micro-receiver set is designed as 15mm3. From the simulation and experimental results, it is obvious that the proposed micro-power receiver is capable to harvest the magnetic energy, no matter from any direction, and convert the magnetic energy into electric voltage. At last, the fabrication process of the proposed micro-power receiver is proposed and the key components have been successfully completed.

However, the power specification of certain micro-devices has to be in direct current. Therefore, the rectifier circuit (e.g. CMOS AC-DC rectifier) has to be employed to transform the alternating voltage into direct current. In addition, since a lot of locomotive devices (e.g. capsule endoscope) have been reported and become more popular gradually, how to supply a stable and constant power to the locomotive device, which might move, rotate or both any time in six-degrees-of-freedom sense, is a research issue ahead. That is, an adaptive variable power controller applied at the transmitter has to be included so that on the receiver side the power can be always consistent and steady. Those issues will be the future works to be accomplished.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This research was partially supported by National Science Council (Republic of China) with Grant NSC 100-2221-E-006-236-.
